content:
• Monday, November 23, 2015
  • PRSS

    Fred Durham buys the dip in CafePress

    • CafePress (NASDAQ:PRSS) CEO Fred Durham last week purchased just shy of 12K shares of company stock last at an average price of about $4 per share.
    • His purchase comes a few days after the stock was punished following Q3 results - falling to as low as about $3.75 from $4.70. Investors may have been put off by a slowdown in buybacks and management earnings call comments about making investments in the business.
    • PRSS was higher by 5% in today's session to $4.17.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:03 PM
  • CTCT

    Constant Contact -2.1% as Stifel joins Roth in cutting to Sell

    • Constant Contact (NASDAQ:CTCT) fell 2.1% today after Stifel Nicolaus downgrades shares to Sell, from Hold.
    • Shares closed at $30.94, still slightly below the $32 offer price from Endurance International Group (EIGI -1.8%).
    • Stifel joined Roth Capital with a Sell rating on the stock; Roth downgraded the company twice in a few days after expecting no competing bid was likely to come in against Endurance International's offer for the firm.
    • Roth had suggested the upside of the deal's completion wasn't worth the downside risk of the deal's failure since another firm was unlikely to join in.
    • Previously: Roth downgrades Constant Contact again, to Sell (Nov. 06 2015)
    • Previously: Constant Contact EPS of $0.19 (Nov. 05 2015)
    • Previously: Roth: Competing bid unlikely for Constant Contact (Nov. 03 2015)
    • Previously: Constant Contact up 21.7% on sale to cloud hosting company (Nov. 02 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:04 PM
  • PSEM

    Phibro Animal Health +1.9%; joining SmallCap 600

    • Along with CSRA joining the S&P 500 to replace Computer Sciences Corp., S&P indices said that Phibro Animal Health (PAHC -1.4%) will join the S&P SmallCap 600 after trading on Wednesday.
    • Phibro shares were up 1.9% after hours.
    • Phibro will replace Pericom Semiconductor (NASDAQ:PSEM) in the SmallCap 600, as it's due to be acquired by fellow SmallCap 600 constituent Diodes.
    • Previously: CSRA joining S&P 500; CSC replacing Apollo in S&P 400 (Nov. 23 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:40 PM
  • DDAY

    Viggle -6.9%, receives delisting warning from Nasdaq

    • Viggle (VGGL -6.9%) today noted that on Friday, it got a delisting warning from Nasdaq after 30 consecutive business days below a minimum closing bid price of $1.
    • The company will get a cure period of 180 days (until May 18) to regain compliance, if it raises closing bid price over $1.00 for 10 straight business days.
    • Shares last closed over $1.00 on Oct. 8; they've lost 49.4% of value over the past month to settle at $0.43 today.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:28 PM | 1 Comment
  • AJRD

    Aerojet Rocketdyne gets $1.4B in contracts from NASA, Boeing

    • Aerojet Rocketdyne (NYSE:AJRD) +4.6% AH after saying it landed two contracts related to manned space travel worth nearly $1.4B.
    • AJRD was awarded a $1.16B contract by NASA to restart production of the RS-25 main engine for the space shuttle, which will be used as a launch motor for deep space missions to Mars; the Mars launches will use four RS-25 motors in a single launch, with an unprecedented lift capacity of up to 130 metric tons.
    • Separately, AJRD signed a contract with Boeing (NYSE:BA) valued at nearly $200M for a propulsion system for the Starliner crew module for getting U.S. astronauts to the International Space Station.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:41 PM | 1 Comment
  • BHC

    Ackman raises stake in Valeant to 9.9%, shares +3.5% AH

    • Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) +3.5% AH after Bill Ackman's Pershing Square discloses it raised its stake in the beaten-down company to 9.9%.
    • The fund bought 2.1M common shares and call options tied to 12.5M shares for a total of $475M, and sold options totaling $169M.
    • Pershing Square now beneficially owns 34.1M shares, which include 21.6M common shares and 12.5M shares underlying options.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:08 PM | 65 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: XRX +7.4%. CXRX-OLD +6.6%. PPP +6.5%. TEDU +6.5%. TCK +5.1%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: BRCD -7.3%. FIG -5.6%. YY -3.1%. APOL -2.1%. POST -1.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM | 6 Comments
  • CPRT

    Copart names new CFO, launches buyback; shares +2.4%

    • Along with its FQ1 results, Copart (NASDAQ:CPRT) has announced Jeffrey Law, formerly the CFO of truck/trailer part distributor FleetPride and before that a principal at P-E firm TPG Capital, is its new CFO, effective Jan. 4. He replaces William Franklin, who will remain Copart's EVP for U.S. operations and shared services.
    • The car auction site and marketing service provider has also announced it plans to buy back up to 7.32M shares (6.1% of outstanding shares) at prices between $38 and $41 through a Dutch auction tender offer set to run from Nov. 24 to Dec. 23. At $41, Copart would be spending $300M on the buyback.
    • Shares have risen to $38.10 after hours.
    • Copart's FQ1 miss, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM
  • XRX

    Icahn discloses 7.1% stake in Xerox; shares +8.7%

    • Carl Icahn has disclosed a 7.13% stake (72.2M shares) in Xerox (NYSE:XRX), and says he plans to hold talks with management. The stake makes Icahn Xerox's second-largest shareholder. (13D filing)
    • From the 13D filing: "The Reporting Persons acquired their positions in the Shares in the belief that the Shares were undervalued. The Reporting Persons intend to have discussions with representatives of the Issuer's management and board of directors relating to improving operational performance and pursuing strategic alternatives, as well as the possibility of board representation."
    • The copier maker and BPO/document services provider has jumped to $11.69 after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:13 PM | 16 Comments
  • VISN

    VisionChina Media -2.4% after revenues, metrics fall in Q3

    • VisionChina Media (NASDAQ:VISN) is down 2.4% after hours following a Q3 report where revenues fell nearly 22% but rose slightly from Q2 and net loss widened to $5M.
    • Total broadcast hours fell 15% to 32,340 hours; advertising minutes sold dropped to 207,532 from 363,927, and average minutes per hour dropped to 6.42 from 9.58.
    • Gross profit dropped to $3.2M from a year-ago $7.6M, and advertising service gross margin narrowed to 13.6% from the previous 25.4%.
    • It's guiding to Q4 ad service revenue of $16M-$16.5M vs. current quarter ad service revenues of $23M.
    • Conference call to come at 8 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:13 PM
  • YY

    YY down 4.3% after mixed Q3; gross margin pressure weighs on EPS

    • YY had a Q3 gross margin of 39.2%, up slightly from Q2's 38.6% but down from 51.7% a year ago. The company blames a revenue mix shift towards user-generated content, higher music/entertainment revenue-sharing payments, and investments in YY's Huya online broadcasting service.
    • Also weighing: Operating expenses rose 91.3% Y/Y to $63.1M, thanks largely to stock compensation growth and a one-time charge, and a $5.8M forex loss was recorded due to the conversion of renminbi to dollars in an offshore account.
    • On an RMB basis, online music/entertainment revenue rose 60% Y/Y to $134.4M. However, online gaming revenue fell 28% to $26.5M, thanks to a 30.7% drop in paying users to 336K. The decline came in spite of an increase in operated games to 283 from 183 a year ago.
    • Online dating revenue rose 169.5% Y/Y on an RMB basis to $27.2M, and other Internet value-added service revenue (Huya, membership fees, etc.) 93.6% to $35.1M. Online dating paid users rose 43.1% to 219K, with ARPU rising 88.1% to RMB788.
    • As was the case last quarter, no formal sales guidance has been provided in the earnings report. CEO David Li notes "intensifying competition and widespread softness in the online gaming market" is weighing on gaming revenue, and states YY will "focus on strengthening our pipeline of massive multiplayer online (MMO) games and optimizing our online broadcasting platform.
    • Shares have fallen to $57.05 after hours.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:47 PM | 4 Comments
  • MORN

    Morningstar CTO Goff leaving post to join data analytics firm

    • In an 8-K filing, Morningstar (MORN +1.8%) notes that its chief technology officer Greg Goff has elected to leave the firm effective Dec. 4.
    • Goff will be joining Uptake Technologies, a recently opened Chicago-based data analytics company.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM
  • BRCD

    Brocade -7.4%; soft FQ1 guidance overshadows FQ4 beat

    • Though it beat FQ4 estimates, Brocade (NASDAQ:BRCD) has guided in its earnings slides (.pdf) for FQ1 revenue of $550M-$570M and EPS of $0.23-$0.25, below a consensus of $582.2M and $0.26.
    • Discussing the outlook, the company notes FQ4 services revenue benefited from $3M in "large catch-up billings," and that a line card upgrade cycle that boosted router-related revenue in FY15 "has begun to moderate."
    • Top-line performance: SAN product revenue +5% Q/Q and flat Y/Y at $325M. IP networking product +10% Q/Q and +12% Y/Y to $152M. Global services +6% Q/Q and +8% Y/Y to $94M. SAN director, Ethernet switch, and software sales grew; SAN switches and IP routers fell.
    • Top-line guidance: SAN product revenue is expected to be flat to up 3% Q/Q in FQ1. IP networking product revenue is expected to be down 16%-22% (federal weakness and lower router-related sales). Global services is expected to be down 2%.
    • Financials: Gross margin (non-GAAP) fell 70 bps Q/Q and rose 20 bps Y/Y to 67.9%. Higher spending led op. margin to drop 190 bps Q/Q and 180 bps Y/Y to 25%. $31.1M was spent on buybacks. Brocade ended FQ4 with $566M in cash net of senior/convertible debt and capitalized leases.
    • Shares have fallen to $9.34 after hours.
    • Brocade's FQ4 beat, earnings release (.pdf)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM
  • HOPE

    BBCN gets merger offer from Hanmi Bank

    • The all-stock deal would see BBCN Bancorp (BBCN) owners receive 0.7331 of a share of Hanmi (NASDAQ:HAFC) for each share of BBCN they own. Based on Hanmi's close today of $27.02, this works out to $19.81 per share versus BBCN's close of $18.25.
    • BBCN shareholders would represent about 65% of the combined company.
    • The deal would create the largest Korean-American banking franchise with about $12B in assets and $10B in deposits. Hanmi expects annual cost savings of roughly $50M-$60M (pretax), which represents 18-22% of the combined companies' cash non-interest expense base.
    • Hanmi for months has unsuccessfully tried to engage with BBCN on a deal, necessitating the need today to go public.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM
  • DY

    Dycom Industries beats by $0.23, beats on revenue

    • Dycom Industries (NYSE:DY): FQ1 EPS of $1.24 beats by $0.23.
    • Revenue of $659.27M (+29.2% Y/Y) beats by $33.65M.
    • Shares +3.25%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM | 4 Comments
  • BTU

    Peabody Energy asset sale helpful for buying time, J.P. Morgan says

    • Peabody Energy (BTU +3.6%) has given up much of its early 15% gain but is still higher following Friday's news that it is selling its New Mexico and Colorado coal assets for $358M.
    • J.P. Morgan analysts said earlier that the cash from the sale will be "helpful for maintaining liquidity and buying time," and anticipated the market's approval given the large short interest in many of the coal equities.
    • JPM estimates the three mines in the sale are worth $450M-$540M, which - combined with the $105M reduction in liabilities - puts the deal at the lower end of the firm's valuation range but the $300M reduction in reclamation exposure is helpful; also, the sustainability of production at the Twentymile mine is seen as questionable.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 20 Comments
  • AMBR

    Amber Road up 23.9% on healthy volume

    • Beaten-down Amber Road (NYSE:AMBR) has surged in afternoon trading on volume of 165K shares, soundly above a 3-month daily average of 104K.
    • The cloud trade management software firm remains down 56% YTD after providing light guidance on multiple occasions. Shares go for just 1.6x a 2016 sales consensus of $76.2M. 2015 and 2016 revenue growth consensus estimates are respectively at 5.9% and 10.9%.
    • Short-covering could be helping: 1.59M shares (over 10% of the float) were shorted as of Oct. 30.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • REXX

    Rex Energy downgraded, target cut to $2, at Imperial Capital

    • Rex Energy (REXX -16%) plunges to lows of the day after Imperial Capital downgrades shares to In-line from Outperform with a $2 price target, cut in half from $4.
    • Although Rex maintains a strong hedge book going into 2016, Imperial believes Appalachian producers will be more challenged than some non-Appalachian peers in the core Eagle Ford, Permian, STACK or Haynesville.
    • The firm's believes that with a predicted warmer than normal winter, record high storage, and ~1,500 drilled but uncompleted gas wells, it prefers to sit on the sideline until it sees visibility on an improving landscape for gas in Appalachia.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:34 PM | 2 Comments
  • DRWI

    DragonWave falls to $0.08

    • Following today's selloff, DragonWave's (DRWI -14.6%) market cap is down to $6.2M. 576K shares have been traded thus far, topping a 3-month daily average of 308K.
    • The RF backhaul hardware firm is now valued at a fraction of the $13.1M cash balance (down $5.8M Q/Q) it had at the end of August. Shares have been hammered this year as sales shortfalls fueled solvency fears.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:18 PM
  • ROVI

    Rovi up 6.7% after director discloses 10K-share purchase

    • Nathaniel Lucas discloses he bought 10K ROVI shares last Thursday at $10.42, bringing his total stake to 35,214.
    • The purchase comes less than a month after Rovi plunged in the wake of a Q3 miss blamed on the end of a licensing contract with a consumer electronics OEM.
    • Activist Engaged Capital (won two board seats in May)has continued buying Rovi shares since the Q3 report. Following its most recently-disclosed purchase (on Nov. 10), Engaged owned 1.04M shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:05 PM
  • FNJN

    Judge affirms Finjan's $39.5M jury award in Blue Coat suit; shares +17.9%

    • A Northern California federal judge has affirmed the $39.5M jury award Finjan (NASDAQ:FNJN) was awarded in August for its infringement suit against private security hardware/software firm Blue Coat.
    • Finjan states the parties to the suit "have about 28 days to file post-judgment motions with the District Court, and can file notices of appeal to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit about 30 days after the District Court rules."
    • The company has a second suit against Blue Coat outstanding, and has also sued FireEye, Proofpoint, Palo Alto Networks, Sophos, and Symantec.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:53 PM
  • ARP

    Atlas Resource Partners whacks distribution in return for lender concessions

    • Atlas Resource Partners (ARP -33.6%) is slashed by a third after agreeing to cut its annual distribution to $0.15/unit from $1.30/unit in exchange for certain borrowing concessions from its lenders, including improved terms on its leverage covenants.
    • ARP says its revised borrowing base has been reduced by $50M, or 6.7%, from its prior level to $700M.
    • ARP says its total leverage ratio as of the end of Q3 was ~5.1x; the next borrowing base re-determination is expected to occur in May 2016.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM | 37 Comments
  • AA

    Alcoa +4.5% after confirming Elliott stake, support of plan to split company

    • Alcoa (AA +4.5%) continues to rally following confirmation that Paul Singer’s Elliott Management bought a 6.4% stake in the company, which says it has had "constructive discussions" with Elliott.
    • The activist firm also supports AA's planned spinoff next year, announced in September, of downstream assets into a separate company.
    • “It’s obviously a vote of confidence from a firm that is steeped in strategic actions,” Sterne Agee CRT analyst Josh Sullivan tells Bloomberg.
    • Elliott's stake makes it the second-biggest shareholder in the company after Vanguard Group, which had an 8.21% stake as of Sept. 30.
    • Citigroup’s Brian Yu earlier reiterated his Buy rating on Alcoa, but trimmed his price target by $1 to $12, arguing that an analysis of the spinoff shows AA's stock has potential while warning that lower commodities prices and slowing earnings pose risks.
    • Earlier: CNBC: Elliott Management takes 6.5% stake in Alcoa
     
     
     
     
    | 2:23 PM | 2 Comments
  • QUNR

    Qunar up 11.9% ahead of earnings

    • Qunar (NASDAQ:QUNR) has surged above $40 ahead of tomorrow afternoon's Q3 report. 2.7M shares have been traded, topping a 3-month daily average of 2.35M.
    • China's #2 online travel firm has been quite volatile (but is up only moderately) since Ctrip and Baidu announced on Oct. 26 the former is buying the latter's stake in Qunar, thus giving it control of 45% of Qunar's voting interests.
    • Ctrip delivered a Q3 beat and issued strong Q4 guidance on Nov. 18. Qunar briefly moved higher on the news, but soon more than gave back its gains.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:42 PM
  • ADSK

    Autodesk recovers post-earnings losses; CEO reportedly discussed Alphabet robotics job

    • Down on Friday after providing soft FQ4 sales guidance and an FY16 subscription/billings guidance cut to go with an FQ3 beat, Autodesk (ADSK +3.9%) has more than recovered its losses today.
    • A weekend report from The Information may or may not be playing a role: The site states Autodesk CEO Carl Bass recently talked with Larry Page about becoming the head of Google parent Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) robotics unit. The talks are said to have fallen through "for a mix of reasons," including the amount of control Bass would have over the unit.
    • Sources talking with The Information argue rejections such as Bass' point to an "inherent weakness" in Alphabet's structure: The company still isn't providing its non-Google operating units (they include Nest Labs, Calico, Google Ventures, Google Capital, and A.I. unit DeepMind) the kind of autonomy sought by many entrepreneurs.
    • Andy Rubin, the former head of Google/Alphabet's robotics unit and before that its Android chief, left last year. The WSJ reported at the time Rubin was "facing constraints on his activities at Google." Google/Alphabet has made a string of robotics acquisitions in recent years.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM | 1 Comment
  • APPS

    Digital Turbine, up 4%, lauds new ad partnerships

    • Digital Turbine (NASDAQ:APPS) is up 4% today after announcing it's grown partnerships with top ad agencies -- including WPP, M&C Saatchi, AOL, and Grow Mobile among others -- in time for the holiday season.
    • "We've seen demand for app placements expand well beyond traditional developers and games," says CEO Bill Stone. "Top brands from travel to retail are looking for ways to expand their reach to their customers through branded apps and homescreen placements."
    • In fiscal Q2 earnings, the company had reported that DT Marketplace (its application and content store) had shown DT Content and DT Pay revenues up 6% in constant currency.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM
  • SN

    Sanchez Energy upgraded to Buy at KLR on production expectations

    • Sanchez Energy (SN +7.2%) is sharply higher after KLR Group upgrades shares to Buy from Accumulate with an $8 price target, citing expectations that Q4 production will come in ahead of the company's guidance.
    • KLR also notes rig program action in the next few years with a commodity price recovery.
    • Late last week, SN said it received lender commitments to change the borrowing base under its $1.5B first lien revolving credit facility to $500M from $550M with an unchanged elected commitment of $300M.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:05 PM
  • PAH-OLD

    Platform Specialty announces 1M-plus share insider buy by three execs

    • Platform Specialty Products (PAH-OLD +6.2%) is higher after reporting that its Chairman, COO and CFO all recently bought a combined 1M-plus shares in the company, including a 500K share purchase by Chairman Martin Franklin.
    • PAH has dropped 8.5% in the week following its worse than expected Q3 earnings results, but had moved back to earlier levels in recent days.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM | 1 Comment
  • GPRO

    GoPro slumps after (another) bearish Barron's column; Ambarella also off (updated)

    • "As it turns out, we weren’t pessimistic enough," writes Barron's in a weekend column on GoPro (GPRO -3.9%), taking a victory lap over its downbeat September write-up on the action camera leader in response to its fall plunge. Don't expect a similar column in the near-term for its Alibaba piece.
    • Barron's: "We’ve always argued that the brand has some value. And the company is planning to launch a camera-equipped drone next year, which is sure to stoke new excitement on Wall Street. But the fundamental risk hasn’t changed for the company. For now, GoPro remains very much a one-trick pony."
    • GoPro is below $20 again, and video processor supplier Ambarella (AMBA -4%) is once more going in the same direction. Ambarella, which reports in 10 days, outperformed GoPro last week.
    • Update: Also of note: Pac Crest has cut its Ambarella target by $25 to $77, while reiterating an Overweight rating. The firm still considers shares undervalued, and cites drones, IP security cameras, and police body cameras as positive catalysts.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:54 PM | 66 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: KBIO +114%. EFUT +62%. MCUR +37%. CANF +38%. CLDN +25%. UNXL +26%. GENE +24%. MOC +20%. ROSG-OLD +17%. AEZS +17%.
    • Losers: ARP -31%. PRQR -29%. APDN -27%. ACI -19%. ERB -16%. SLTB -14%. PARR -14%. OTC:CDTI -13%. OTC:ATLS -11%. DLHC -11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 12 Comments
  • RL

    High-end apparel stocks pick up steam

    • High-end global retail stocks are on the move as some analysts see the sector as oversold.
    • A positive step forward for trade talks between China and the U.S. may also be contributing to the mini-rally.
    • Gainers: Ralph Lauren (RL +1.8%), Guess (GES +3.3%), Coach (COH +2%), Michael Kors (KORS +1.8%), Vera Bradley (VRA +1.6%), Kate Spade (KATE +2.6%), PVH Corp (PVH +1.6%).
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM
  • HIMX

    Himax +4.8%; Morgan Stanley launches coverage, talks up AR/VR potential

    • "Given the segment's momentum, we believe 2016 will be an inflection point for [augmented reality] smart glasses," writes Morgan Stanley's Charlie Chan, launching coverage on Himax (NASDAQ:HIMX) with an Overweight rating and $8.50 target.
    • Chan declares Himax, which supplies LCoS microdisplays for Google Glass and is believed by some analysts to have a supply deal for Microsoft's HoloLens, well-positioned to benefit AR/VR headset adoption. He also expects the recent launch of OLED driver and TDDI (integrated touch controller/display driver) ICs to strengthen Himax's display driver business.
    • The coverage comes two weeks after Baird started Himax at Outperform, shortly following the company's Q3 report.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM | 7 Comments
  • TRUE

    TrueCar names ex-AutoTrader chief its new CEO; shares +10.5%

    • Chip Perry, AutoTrader's CEO from 1997-2013 and after that the CEO of Rent.com parent RentPath, has been named TrueCar's (NASDAQ:TRUE) CEO, effective Dec. 15.
    • Perry replaces founder Scott Painter, who announced plans to step down as CEO in August; Painter will also be stepping down as chairman. The hiring comes two months after president and principal operating officer John Krafcik left for Google.
    • TrueCar has soared on the news. Shares remain down 64% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:11 PM | 1 Comment
  • TAC

    TransAlta +12 on Alberta climate change plan

    • TransAlta (TAC +12.2%) soars following the Alberta government's announced plan to phase out of coal generation and accelerate wind and solar power construction, which would give the renewable energy producer an edge over competitors.
    • TAC already was planning to phase out most of its coal generation by 2030, while competitor Capital Power’s (OTCPK:CPXWF) coal fleet was expected to operate beyond then.
    • The accelerated phase out that will affect six coal-power plants in Alberta will result in C$12B of foregone revenue to plant owners, including V$1B for TAC and C$2B for Capital Power, but producers are expected to be compensated for the phase out, "an important counterbalance," according to one analyst.
    • TAC is upgraded to Sector Perform from Underperform with a $7 price target, up from $6, at RBC, which remains concerned about the decommissioning of coal plants, lower long-term power prices, and a dividend cut.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM
  • EA

    EA, Activision, Take-Two lower after GameStop disappoints

    • Major videogame makers are trading lower today despite modest broader market gains, after key retailer GameStop posted disappointing earnings and guidance today.
    • Electronic Arts (NASDAQ:EA) is off 5.8%, Activision Blizzard (NASDAQ:ATVI) down 0.6% and Take-Two Interactive (NASDAQ:TTWO) off 1.7% following the results.
    • Revenues declined at GameStop (counting currency effects) and its sales mix tilted toward pre-owned games, as the percentage of sales devoted to new video game hardware and new software both declined.
    • Previously: GameStop craters after earnings and guidance disappoint (Nov. 23 2015)
    • Previously: GameStop misses by $0.05, misses on revenue (Nov. 23 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:55 AM | 12 Comments
  • PSTG

    Pure Storage, Violin Memory sell off again in wake of Nimble's earnings

    • Pure Storage (PSTG -3.7%) is now down 19% since hybrid array vendor Nimble Storage posted an FQ3 miss and issued soft FQ4 guidance last Thursday afternoon. Enterprise all-flash array peer Violin Memory (VMEM -9.2%) is down 14% over the same time.
    • Nimble was hit with nearly a dozen downgrades following the numbers, which the company (much more SMB-dependent than Pure and Violin) blamed on a delayed payoff for enterprise investments and the impact of its recent enterprise focus on SMB sales. Potentially relevant to Pure/Violin: Analysts raised concerns about incumbent storage vendors (EMC, NetApp, etc.) competing more aggressively over deals as public cloud adoption shrinks their addressable market.
    • Both companies have made new post-IPO lows; Pure is now nearly $3 below its $17 October IPO price. Violin reports on Dec. 2, and Pure on Dec. 3.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:47 AM | 4 Comments
  • PRQR

    ProQR Therapeutics slumps 25% on delay of CF trial data

    • Thinly traded micro cap ProQR Therapeutics (PRQR -25.4%) drops on higher-than-average volume, albeit on turnover of less than 100K shares, in response its announcement that top-line data from its ongoing clinical studies of QR-010 in cystic fibrosis will be delayed until mid-to-late 2016 due to slower-than-expected patient enrollment.
    • Two studies are in progress: a 32-subject open-label Phase 1 (NCT02564354) assessing QR-010 in F508del-positive CF patients and a Phase 1/2 (NCT02532764), a randomized, 64-subject, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in adults homozygous (having two identical pairs of genes) for F508del CF. The F508del (delta) is the most common CF mutation, affecting more than 70% of all CF patients.
    • CF is caused by mutations in a protein called CFTR. QR-010 is an inhaled therapy designed to repair the genetic defect in RNA which will result in the synthesis of a normal healthy CFTR protein.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:44 AM
  • GEC

    Unwired Planet up 17.8% on U.K. legal win over Samsung/Huawei

    • The U.K. High Court has ruled Samsung and Huawei infringe a standards-essential 4G patent asserted by Unwired Planet (UPIP).
    • UPIP states it's "not yet known" whether Samsung/Huawei will appeal, and that (per U.K. law) it will be "entitled to reimbursement of a substantial portion of its legal expenses" related to this portion of the case.
    • The ruling covers the first of five U.K. infringement trials scheduled to occur through the summer of 2016. A sixth trial covering the proper application of FRAND licensing principles for standards-essential IP is set for Oct. 2016.
    • In 2013, UPIP bought 2,185 mobile patents and applications from Ericsson, as well as a commitment to receive another 100 "patent assets" annually from 2014-2018; Ericsson receives a portion of the revenue produced by the patents. UPIP received an adverse ruling in May for a suit filed against Apple, and one last December for a suit filed against Google.

  • LLNW

    Limelight plans to appeal Akamai ruling to Supreme Court

    • Limelight (LLNW -2.4%) will ask the Supreme Court to review a recent appeals court (CAFC) ruling declaring the company guilty of directly infringing a CDN patent owned by bigger rival Akamai (NASDAQ:AKAM).
    • The S.C., which only hears a tiny % of appealed cases, previously ruled (in a decision applauded by many tech companies) Limelight couldn't be held liable for inducing infringement of the Akamai patent by its users. However, the CAFC later ruled Limelight's control over its users makes it guilty of direct infringement.
    • CEO Bob Lento: "We strongly disagree with the unduly broad standard for direct infringement created by the August 13, 2015 en banc opinion by the Federal Circuit. We are hopeful that the Supreme Court will address this erroneous decision." Limelight is down 50% from the Aug. 12 close, and 20% since the CAFC rejected an appeal of its decision on Nov. 16.

Excluding the charge, operating expenses were 11% of revenue ($87.3M) vs. 11.6% in Q2 and 10.9% a year ago. Trina ended Q3 with $486.1M in cash and $1.17B in bank borrowings ($1B short-term).
    • Top-line performance: Q3 module shipments rose 38.3% Q/Q and 60.1% Y/Y to 1.7GW, topping guidance of 1.4GW-1.5GW (drove the revenue beat). 350MW of shipments were for Trina's own projects. Shipments are expected to total 1.5GW-1.6GW in Q4. 251.9MW of projects were connected to the grid, and record shipments were seen in China and the U.S.

  • CANF

    Can-Fite's CF102 shows promising preclinical results in NASH; shares up 42% premarket

    • Nano cap Can-Fite BioPharma (NYSEMKT:CANF) jumps 42% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement of that it is expanding the development of CF102, an oral small molecule drug candidate currently in Phase 2 development for liver cancer, into non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Its decision was based on encouraging preclinical results that showed CF102's beneficial effects on several NASH-related metrics.
    • In an animal model of NASH, CF102 improved liver pathology as measured by a significant reduction in NAFLD score, reduced liver-to-body weight, improved histology, decreased plasma ALT (liver enzyme) and triglyceride levels and a decrease in steatosis, ballooning and lobular inflammation, all compared to placebo.
    • No specific guidance is provided as to when clinical studies might begin.
    • The company has also filed a patent covering CF102 in the treatment of NASH.
    • CF102 binds to a protein that is highly expressed in tumor cells called A3 adenosine receptor.

  • PFE

    Pfizer and Allergan agree to merge

    • It's official. Pfizer (NYSE:PFE) and Allergan (NYSE:AGN) agree to merge in a $160B deal, the largest inversion transaction on record. AGN shareholders will receive 11.3 shares of the combined company for each AGN share while PFE shareholders will receive one share of the combined firm for each PFE share. The deal should close in H2 2016. After the merger, the company will do business as "Pfizer plc" and trade under the "PFE" symbol. It will be domiciled in Ireland (pro forma adjusted effective tax rate expected to be 17 - 18%).
    • Pfizer shareholders will own ~56% of the combined firm while Allergan shareholders will own ~44%. Pfizer chief Ian Read will be Chairman & CEO while Allergan chief Brent Saunders will be President & COO.
    • The merger should be neutral to Pfizer's non-GAAP EPS in 2017, accretive in 2018, more than 10% accretive in 2019 and accretive in the high teens in 2020. Operating cash flow should exceed $25B beginning in 2018.
    • The company will make a decision on splitting its innovative and established businesses no later than the end of 2018.
    • Separately, Pfizer will execute a $5B share repurchase program in H1 2016. It has ~$5.4B remaining on its previously announced buyback plan.
    • Pfizer will host a conference call this morning at 8:30 am ET to discuss the transaction.
    • Slide presentation
